contextId.information: Deep sadness is spoken of as if the person's heart is broken. AT: "people who are very sad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This refers to people who are righteous. AT: "the righteous people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This refers to the people who are meek. AT: "the meek people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This does not refer to specific people. This refers to people who are righteous. AT: "the righteous person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This refers to the wicked people. AT: "The wicked people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This refers to having few possessions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This refers to the wicked people in general. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

This refers to the rebellious people. The abstract word "rebellious" can be stated as an action. AT: "those who rebel against him" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This refers to meek people in general. AT: "Meek people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
These adjectives can be translated as noun phrases. AT: "wicked people ... unrighteous people ... cruel people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
Here "the poor" and "fatherless" are nominal adjectives. They can be stated as adjectives. AT: "those who are poor and those who are orphans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This nominal adjective can be stated as an adjective. AT: "wicked people" or "those who are wicked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This nominal adjective can be stated as an adjective. AT: "arrogant people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
The adjective "righteous" can be translated as a noun phrase. AT: "righteous people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This refers to wicked people. AT: "the wicked people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This refers to destitute people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

The words "wicked" and "deceitful" refer to people. They have similar meanings and emphasize how bad these people are. AT: "For wicked and deceitful men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The adjective "dead" may be translated with a noun phrase. AT: "People who are dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

This refers to people who are inexperienced or who cannot care for themselves. The adjective can be translated as a noun phrase. AT: "those who are naive" or "those who are helpless" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This nominal adjective can be stated as an adjective. AT: "The proud people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This nominal adjective can be stated as an adjective. AT: "Arrogant people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
The adjective "treacherous" can be translated as a noun phrase. AT: "treacherous people" or "those who betray me" or "my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
The adjective "wicked" can be translated as a noun phrase. AT: "wicked people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This nominal adjective can be stated as adjectives. AT: "for oppressed people" or "for those whom other people oppress" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
